label: 狂歌
本: Edo Culture: Daily Life and Diversions in Urban Japan, 1600-1868 . University of Hawai'i Press . 1997
説明文: Literally crazy verses"－satirical or humorous poems in 5-7-5-7-7 syllable form. Most kyoka poets assumed pseudonyms that included complex puns or literary allusions. These names are usually untranslatable; many are humorous only if the incompatibility of the semantic and phonetic values of the Sino-Japanese ideographs is sensed. Some authors chose to parody older poets: thus Hamabe no Kurohito ("dark man on the waterfront") is probably a spoof on Yamabe no Akahito, a Nara-period poet. Other names may allude to personal conditions: Yadoya no Meshimori, for example, means "servant at the inn" and refers to the fact that the poet ran an inn at Kodenma-cho in Edo.［浜辺黒人、山部赤人、奈良、宿屋飯盛、小伝馬町、江戸］"
